utterances: Your program has been in operation now since 2003.
Has there been a decrease in HIV and hepatitis C?
You know, any scientist listening will know that to determine the impact of a small program on population level rates of HIV infection, that takes years.
But while one is waiting to answer that question, what we typically do is look at - well, is the site having an impact on the behaviors that lead to HIV infection?
So in our case, we studied whether the site was having a impact on syringe sharing rates.
And what we found was people who use the site on a frequent basis are 70 percent less likely to report syringe sharing than those who do not.
It seems that you could very well argue that by allowing users to come in and inject these drugs without any fear of being thrown into jail is really enabling their addictions.
We now have data on this showing that there's actually been a 33 percent increase in the rate of detoxification program use since the site opened.
So the advantage of the injection facility is, is that it provides an opportunity to have a more sustained contact with people and provide them with referrals to appropriate services.
When they use this facility, it's very different than when they inject in public.
When they inject in public, they inject very quickly, they inject all the drugs they have on them, so that they get them in them before they have run into the police.
In the facility, they are actually able to the things that help reduce the risk of overdose.
I'm curious how the law enforcement in Vancouver feels about all of this.
I would imagine that it might drive them somewhat crazy, the drug enforcement officers, knowing that there are people using drugs and there's no repercussion for it.
Certainly there are initially was some opposition to this type of initiative.

What we do know is that a number of police officers are actually referring people to the site, and most recently when we had to apply for an extension of the facility, the chief of the Vancouver police wrote a letter supporting the extension.
Dr. Thomas Kerr is principal investigator at Insite and a research scientist at the British Columbia Center for Excellence in HIV AIDS.
Thank you so much.

Twitter has permanently suspended conspiracy theorist Alex Jones and his Infowars channel from its platform.

Hey, Tony.
Hey, thanks for having me.
So Alex Jones has said a whole lot of very offensive things over the years, trafficked in hate speech and conspiracy theories.
Many of these have transpired on Twitter.

And when Twitter announced this in a series of tweets yesterday, it didn't point to a specific thing that Jones and Infowars had done over the better part of the past 24 hours.
But it wasn't the first time that he had violated the rules.

envoy Ibrahim Gambari himself.

envoy and the military leaders, I think her face would have looked a lot different.

Welcome to the program.
Thank you.
Can you tell us what we know about the current leader, General Than Shwe?
How does he maintain control of people there?
Well, Than Shwe spent some of his formative years in the department of psychological warfare.
So he's certainly very well versed in the strategic use of political violence to create fear.
So much of what he does is about creating just enough fear to paralyze the population and to maintain that.
Monique, I think it may be hard for people here in the West to understand what it's like to live in a society like that.
You spent a fair bit of time there.
Can you explain kind of the psychological toll that it takes on the people of Myanmar to live under some of these practices?
I think probably the most insidious thing that occurs is that the enormous amount of censorship over time creates self-censorship.
So Burmese people eventually become complicit with the military regime in perpetuating what occurs because they stop themselves from thinking about freedom.
They stop themselves from thinking pro-democracy thoughts and from taking part in the kinds of activities that are banned because they might lead to democracy.
The other thing that's very insidious is after a while that barrage of propaganda, it's very hard to psychologically keep yourself apart from it.
And we're talking about now almost the third generation born under dictatorship.

So when the regime talks about a love of motherland, a need to protect the country against foreigners buying off the country's resources, it resonates just a little bit with Burmese people and it sets up just enough doubt in their mind that they can be brought along just a little bit.
The state has pretty much shut down the people's access to information.
They've closed down phone lines and, you know, shut off the Internet, but there's still a fair amount of information that's managing to get out of Myanmar.
